LETTER was recently handed to one of the Editors of the NEWSLETTER, addressed to "The President of the Dramatic Club, Johns
*

Hopkins University." Just why it was consigned to our tender
mercies, we do not know. Perhaps by accident; perhaps by design.
*

If there were design in it, assuredly it was a hint that now is the
*
time for the annual clarion call through the pages of this paper for
a mass-meeting to organize a Dramatic Club. Observance has so
• VVIOVIIIIVVVVV
honored this custom that now an autumn would feel lonesome withV V
out it ! Of course, nothing has come of it—so far. (Last year, if
we remember rightly, seven men attended the organization meeting.)
But there is no reason why something should not come of it. "When Hopkins moves to
Homewood" is a proverb, and was once almost a synonym for "never," and yet we have
moved there to the extent of one of the best athletic fields in the country. The suggestion
that we have a Dramatic Club is not chimerical. We could have one if we tried. We have
teams and good teams at Hopkins. We have Musical Clubs. Indeed, when we come to
think of it, we have even a college paper. Hopkins is small; "We're few, but we're—er!—
mighty select." If we want a Dramatic Club, we can have it. Do we want it?

collect the largest number of subscriptions from their class. If these rules are to be followed,
the Club will increase enormously in size in a year or two. Last year there were ten on it.
Now, as we said, the three Hopkins Dances are social, not class, affairs. Would it
not be better to have the Committee representative of the social side of University life without
regard to classes ? The social side of life here is represented mainly by the Fraternities. We
suggest that in years to come each Fraternity be allowed to choose its representative on the
Cotillon Club, and the non-Fraternity element of the University be represented by a nonFraternity man. We doubt greatly if this advice will be followed. Good advice seldom is.

HAT is the matter with the Freshmen ? There are a lot of husky
men in the class that are never seen at foot-ball practices. What we
want on the team is beef, and every hefty fellow in the University
ought to be in the cage every afternoon at half past four. What if
you are not played on the 'Varsity all the time the first day you come
out ? Keep it up ! Attend the practices regularly and learn the
signals, and sooner or later your chance will come.
ttigittl
We want to show what we can do in foot-ball this fall under
changed conditions. To do it the team needs the support of every
man in the University. Some can play, others can root; but every
one can buy a season ticket. Let each and every Hopkins man do his best, and this year's
team will be a rousing success,

ID you enjoy "Strong-heart" and "Noah's Ark" last year? In other
words, did you enjoy the two Hopkins Nights? Of course, you did!
Every one did. There is no reason why such pleasures should not
come to us again this year—not twice as last year, but three or four
times a year. We have a bully crowd of Seniors. The NEwsLETTIk is proud of them. They have done a lot for the University,
and if they get up several first-rate Hopkins Nights, they will be
doing a lot more—and incidentally will help their ''Hullabaloo."

And don't wait till 'way next February. Get up a Hopkins Night soon, please.

Corner, 3rd, and Mr. W. V. Johnson, both of the Class of 1909, as regular members of the
Editorial board. Mr. Corner becomes Assistant News Editor, and Mr. Johnson Assistant
Athletic Editor. Other elections will probably take place in November.

AUREA BIBL1A;
Or, The Golden Bible.
The red light of the Western sun was slowly
deepening and darkening in the great rotunda
of the reading room of the British Museum.
It was the stateliest hour of all the twenty-four
stately hours which make up every day in the
massive gray stone pile. It was likewise the
quietest hour. The crowd of students who
had been toiling all the afternoon were departing one by one ; the crowd of students—almost
as large—who work there evening after evening until midnight had not yet come.
It was nearly dark in the corner where Eugene was reading. The familiar figure of the
Keeper of Printed Books, (Dr. Richard Garnett, who has since died), passed .by him. The
old man nodded kindly to the young student,
who scarcely returned the courtesy, so deeply
was he interested in the old volume which lay
before him.
To a chance observer there was nothing remarkable about the book, save only its evident
antiquity; and to the frequenter of the Museum, who is familiar with the sight of the
great Bulls of Ninevah, old books—even
"cradle books"—seem as though made yesterday.
Eugene turned over the leaves one after one,
fondling them lovingly. The book had no
title page—it was printed before the days of
such—but at the top of the first page was the
following legend in Gothic type:

a machine which looked not unlike a modern

Before the young writer was a fresh, white
page, on which the black ink, scarce dry,
shone merrily. "LIBER MANUALIS," the book
began. The youth carefully reddened the L,
and, reading on down the page, came to "INCIPIT FELICITER." Here was a good omen,
thought he, and with a little nervous tremor,
to which the unevenness of the line bore witness, he underlined the words lightly in red.
It was the same room several months later.
The little blond-haired printer was standing
beside the young man. His hand rested on
the lad's shoulder. He looked at him kindly.
"You will get over it, my boy," he said. "All
women are alike. Out of sight, out of mind!
If she would not wait a short year for you, do
you think she was really worth having for always?"
"'Please do not talk like that, Herr Johann.
She was and is an angel. She has forgotten
me, but who am I to be remembered? Only
—it does seem a little hard just now, when I
was working so eagerly—for her."
"Be a brave lad," said the printer. "Go back
to your work. It's a brave art, a wonderful
art. Forget all the women and lose yourself
in your work. Go on now with the Golden
Bible. You've nearly finished it, haven't you ?"
"I will go on—I will try to forget, Herr Johann. But I can never, no, never, go back
to the red initials of the Aurea Biblia. I must
leave it unfinished, and for my sake, though
it's a foolish whim, let the initials of this particular copy remain white. Look, it's the copy
I beg-an with last May. Here, under this incipit felicitcr, I made a bright red line. I was
a fool."

"Antony and Cleopatra" is the greatest of
the-Roman plays. Technically it is not planned
with the skill of "Julius Czesar," but the action
is more varied, the sphere of interest larger,
and the passions more deeply moved than in
the tragedy which historically precedes it. The
marvelous banquet scene, at the close of which
the third ruler of the world is carried out by
his slaves, teaches as great a moral lesson as
does the scene in "Othello" where Cassius is
intoxicated.
"0 that men should put an enemy in their mouths
To take away their brains."

It is at once interesting and pathetic to the
student of human nature that these two terrible scenes—and the "wan mirth of the mirthless fool" in "Lear--teaching such terrible
and fundamental moral lessons, yet never fail
to provoke as many roars of laughter from the
audience as do the orgies of Sir Toby ,or
of Stephan°.
In his admirable new life of Shakespeare
(mentioned, by the way, in the last number of
the NEWS-LETTER) Prof. Walter Raleigh expresses the opinion that the death of Cleopatra
in Shakespeare "falls short" of the same scene
as described by Plutarch. I cannot agree with
him. The final scene of the tragedy compares
for fervor, for passion, for sublimity, with the
close of "Lear," and to me, at least, is finer art
than is the consummation of the tragedy in
"Othello." Faithfulness to her lover is in the
end of more importance to Cleopatra than her
passion for him, and her following him even
to death gives her the right to say: "Husband, I come!"
To mention Professor Raleigh again:
speaking of anachronisms in Shakespeare, he
writes:
"There are clocks in 'Julius Cesar,' a paper
mill and printing in 'Henry VI,' etc, etc. InRoman plays, Shakespeare

THE NEW BOOK SHELF.

Last month the fifteenth volume of the New
Variorum Shakespeare—"Antony and Cleopatra"—was published, being the first volume
which Dr. Furness has issued since the fall of
1904.

"0 that I were
Upon the hill of Basan to outroar
The horned herd."

The only comment on this latter fact in Dr.
Furness' edition is quoted from Singer, who
suggests that Antony may have learnt the

6

'1'1 E NEWS-LETTER.

psalms from Herod, who was his friend. In a
recent letter to the present writer Dr. Furness
writes:
"As to the hills of Basan, I gave the references from the Bible merely to show where
Antony found his allusion, and not to any conversation with Herod, as Singer most foolishly suggests."
The passage is simply one of the many
anachronisms in Shakespeare.
The various prefaces to the New Variorum
Shakespeare form in themselves charming essays. In the preface to the present volume it
is interesting to note that Dr. Furness considers Dryden's Ali for Love "an admirable
play," an opinion long held by the present
writer, which it is pleasing to find sanctioned
by the highest authority.
A most interesting and instructive portion
of the book is the essay on the various "versions" of this tragedy, which have been written
from the middle of the sixteenth century to
the time of Mr. Bernard Shaw. It is a striking fact that the first "regular" tragedy in the
literatures both of France and of Germany is
on the subject of Cleopatra.
I cannot close this notice without a reference to the kindly humor of the venerable editor, which turns up at unexpected times in
the volumes of this wonderful Shakespeare.
Several members of the faculty here at Hopkins have the honor of Dr. Furness' friendship,
among them Prof. Bright and Prof. Haupt.
Before I had that privilege a New York gentleman (who, I hear, has been suggested as the
Turnbull lecturer this winter) described Dr.
Furness to me as "a concentrated ray of sunshine." The diffusion of this "ray" through
his pages makes the darkest vault of discussion
"a feasting presence full of light."

deserves to rank with Boswell and Lockhart
among the great biographies of the language.
The present Lord Tennyson, it must be remembered, wrote an official biography. He
was not a great critic nor a great writer. The
fact that he was the poet's son was in itself
a hinderance rather than a help. But the
Memoir contains nearly all data for future biographies, besides a store of loving personal
reminiscences.
Mr. Benson is a careful and trained writer.
Besides the volumes of essays, which are
widely known, he has contributed three volumes to the English Men of Letters series.
Of ihese, the life of "Rossetti" is not entirely
satisfactory (indeed, I have yet to read one
that is), and the "Pater" is not really complete, additional data having since been furnished by relatives to Mr. Thomas,Wright, the
author of the "official" life of Pater.
But in writing this little volume on Tennyson Mr. Benson has been eminently successful.
Of course, he can give now no new facts about
a life, the minute details of which are known
to almost everyone. It is in the criticism,
which makes up a large part of the book, that
he excells. I cannot, however, agree with
some of his opinions, notably his support of
Coventry Patmore's harsh dictum regarding
the poetry of "In Memoriam." A very charming chapter is written on Tennyson's opinions
of various poets—Shakespeare, Milton, Keats,
'Wordsworth, etc. It is interesting and touching to know that Tennyson died with a volume
of Shakespeare clasped in his hand. This is
told in the Memoir, but from Mr. Benson I
learn for the first time that the book was
opened at and his finger rested on the lines of
Cymbe/inc—

The Y. M. C. A. has made a few changes

Hall. The chapel exercises and meetings,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the novels repels us. Words, words, words!
To say the least Richardson is prolix. But
Richardson is a moral writer. The moral of
the novel, a thing of but little importance to
either Fielding or Smollett, was.of supreme
importance to him. When Pamela or Virtue
Rewarded, appeared the clergy hailed it with
joy. It was to them as assistance from the
enemy. Richardson modestly sums up his
novel in the following sentence:
"Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded, is a series of
familiar letters from a beautiful young damsel to her parents, published in order to cultivate the principles of virtue and religion in the
minds of the youth of both sexes ; a narrative
which has its foundation in truth, and at the
same time that it agreeably entertains by a
variety of curious and affecting incidents, is
entirely divested of all those images which in
too many pieces calculated for amusement
only, tend to inflame the minds that they
should instruct." This is something of a sentence, even, for Richardson.
In this novel we have the struggle of virtue
and vice. Indeed, before I had half finished it,
I was tempted to remark that it was the greatgrand daddy of all Sunday school libraries.
Pamela believes everything is good. She is
the very apotheosis of virtue and submissiveness. Her master is diametrically the opposite. And so the story drags through four
long volumes. At one time it seems that virtue
must lose. Pamela falls in love with her master, but her native innocence helps and stays
her. At last the wicked master weakens. lie
will marry the foolish little girl. For her wedding present she obtains the pardon of the very
people who had ill-treated her. And so the
story goes.
But is Pamela a real person ? I should say
certainly not, although the ladies would contradict me. The master is, but his very vices
tend to show all the more the almost impossible goodness of Pamela.
Clarissa liar/owe is much like Pamela.
Here we have a delightful picture of family
life : a stern old demon of a father, an envious elder sister, a regular hot-blooded bulldog of an elder son, a couple of surly old
uncles and a beautiful young daughter, Clarissa.
But the characters in Clarissa Harlow are

more human than those in Pamela. Richardson, in Clarissa HarloTce, gave one character
to English Literature—that of Lovelace.
.Lovelace, with all the malice and venom of a
viper, poses as a brilliant, witty, young beau.
lie only cares for those who offer some resistance to his charms. Lovelace is one of the
least attractive of all Richardson's characters,
but he is the only one who has ever obtained
prominence. He remains today, one of the
characters of English literature, ranking beside Colonel Newcome, Mr. Pickwick, Mr.
Micawber, only how different!
Yet in Clarissa Harlow( Richardson falls
into the same old fault—prolixity. What does
the reader care whether Clarissa Harlowe's
coffin has silver or tin handles? Does it make
any difference to us if the same old coffin is
lined with pink silk or yellow satin ? But it
evidently does matter to the author. I le 'must
write chapters on that subject.
Richardson, seeking to aid morality, unwittingly prejudices the reader against it. He
seems to forget that one well-placed word
has more effect on the reader than twenty
pages of explanation. The reader laughs at
the pathetic parts. in the parts intended to be
elevating, the reader sees only the ranting
preacher.
But Richardson is great. To understand the
English novel you must understand Richardson. When we consider the times in which
Richardson wrote we must admit the excellence of his novels. What ever may be their
faults in execution, their conception was good.
Richardson tried and just missed being a great
novelist. Fielding profited by the novels of
Richardson. Joseph . indrews, published after
Richardson's Pamela, was suggested to him
by the former novel.
Richardson did not understand men. All
his men, with the exception of Sir Charles
Grandison, are villains. And Sir Charles
Grandison seems to have stepped out of a
fashion plate. His letters seem to have been
copied from "M rs. Grundy's Complete LetterWriter." He is about as human as a clothes
dummy. Richardson was a woman's writer.
All his novels were widely read by women.
His popularity was among women. And why?
He understood a woman's mind. He appreciated the fine side of a woman's nature. He

THE NEWS-LETTER.

could sympathize with the feelings of a
woman's heart.
While we are criticising Richardson, let us
give him the credit due him. He was the first
English novelist. No one had ever gone before him, by whose mistakes he could profit.
His novels were all his own. He opened the
path where, years later, Thackeray, Dickens,
Charles Reade and Scott were to follow.

12

And if anything has happened in the
neighborhood of McCoy Hall, which may
not have been observed by us, but which you
think worthy of chronicling, why don't be
bashful;—write it up and hand it in! This
would demand very little exertion on your
part and would help us greatly.
There is another trouble of very different
character which grieves the life of an Editor.
This is the torments inflicted by a malignant
imp, known as the "Printer's Devil," sometimes referred to as 'that devil of a printer."
The hateful creature takes the most violent
and inexplicable dislikes to various harmless
people. In the last number of the NEWSLETTER he made a furious onslaught on several
famous poets. Hugo he maimed into "Hugh;"
the mangled corpse of Burns was scarcely
recognized as ''Bruns;'' he so crushed Plautus
that the proud capital "P" of the Latin
dramatist was deformed into "p;" Mr. Percy
McRaye became "Mr. Percy McVey." The
"Printer's Devil" also had trouble with
Tennyson's "hollow Os and As" with the
result that "Osianna" became "Asianna."
Worse than all these, our President himself
was not safe and Doctor Remsen was exhibited
to our horror-stricken gaze as "Doctor
Renzen." Another queer trait of the creature
is the hydra-like rapidity with which his mis'—multiply.
begotten offspring— misprints'
As fast as one is slain another takes its place.
To speak seriously for a moment, no one
who has not had experience in reading proof
can realize the corrections that have to be
made in "galley-proof,"and even after a second
reading one cannot be sure that no misprints
exist. The last number of the NEws-LETTER
was published hastily owing to some unavoidable delays in getting the advertising arranged
and considering the fact that only one proof
was read, and that hurriedly, the six or seven
misprints need not be a cause of great triumph
to the "Printer's Devil."

Now, as we said, the three Hopkins Dances are social, not class, affairs. Would it

HAT is the matter with the Freshmen ? There are a lot of husky
men in the class that are never seen at foot-ball practices. What we
want on the team is beef, and every hefty fellow in the University
ought to be in the cage every afternoon at half past four. What if
you are not played on the 'Varsity all the time the first day you come
out ? Keep it up ! Attend the practices regularly and learn the
signals, and sooner or later your chance will come.

The red light of the Western sun was slowly
deepening and darkening in the great rotunda
of the reading room of the British Museum.
It was the stateliest hour of all the twenty-four
stately hours which make up every day in the
massive gray stone pile. It was likewise the
quietest hour. The crowd of students who
had been toiling all the afternoon were departing one by one ; the crowd of students—almost
as large—who work there evening after evening until midnight had not yet come.
It was nearly dark in the corner where Eugene was reading. The familiar figure of the
Keeper of Printed Books, (Dr. Richard Garnett, who has since died), passed .by him. The
old man nodded kindly to the young student,
who scarcely returned the courtesy, so deeply
was he interested in the old volume which lay
before him.
To a chance observer there was nothing remarkable about the book, save only its evident
antiquity; and to the frequenter of the Museum, who is familiar with the sight of the
great Bulls of Ninevah, old books—even
"cradle books"—seem as though made yesterday.
Eugene turned over the leaves one after one,
fondling them lovingly. The book had no
title page—it was printed before the days of
such—but at the top of the first page was the
following legend in Gothic type:

Before the young writer was a fresh, white
page, on which the black ink, scarce dry,
shone merrily. "LIBER MANUALIS," the book
began. The youth carefully reddened the L,
and, reading on down the page, came to "INCIPIT FELICITER." Here was a good omen,
thought he, and with a little nervous tremor,
to which the unevenness of the line bore witness, he underlined the words lightly in red.
It was the same room several months later.
The little blond-haired printer was standing
beside the young man. His hand rested on
the lad's shoulder. He looked at him kindly.
"You will get over it, my boy," he said. "All
women are alike. Out of sight, out of mind!
If she would not wait a short year for you, do
you think she was really worth having for always?"
"'Please do not talk like that, Herr Johann.
She was and is an angel. She has forgotten
me, but who am I to be remembered? Only
—it does seem a little hard just now, when I
was working so eagerly—for her."
"Be a brave lad," said the printer. "Go back
to your work. It's a brave art, a wonderful
art. Forget all the women and lose yourself
in your work. Go on now with the Golden
Bible. You've nearly finished it, haven't you ?"
"I will go on—I will try to forget, Herr Johann. But I can never, no, never, go back
to the red initials of the Aurea Biblia. I must
leave it unfinished, and for my sake, though

a fool."

"Antony and Cleopatra" is the greatest of
the-Roman plays. Technically it is not planned
with the skill of "Julius Czesar," but the action
is more varied, the sphere of interest larger,
and the passions more deeply moved than in
the tragedy which historically precedes it. The
marvelous banquet scene, at the close of which
the third ruler of the world is carried out by
his slaves, teaches as great a moral lesson as
does the scene in "Othello" where Cassius is
intoxicated.
"0 that men should put an enemy in their mouths
To take away their brains."

It is at once interesting and pathetic to the
student of human nature that these two terrible scenes—and the "wan mirth of the mirthless fool" in "Lear--teaching such terrible
and fundamental moral lessons, yet never fail
to provoke as many roars of laughter from the
audience as do the orgies of Sir Toby ,or
of Stephan°.
In his admirable new life of Shakespeare
(mentioned, by the way, in the last number of
the NEWS-LETTER) Prof. Walter Raleigh expresses the opinion that the death of Cleopatra
in Shakespeare "falls short" of the same scene
as described by Plutarch. I cannot agree with
him. The final scene of the tragedy compares
for fervor, for passion, for sublimity, with the
close of "Lear," and to me, at least, is finer art
than is the consummation of the tragedy in
"Othello." Faithfulness to her lover is in the
end of more importance to Cleopatra than her
passion for him, and her following him even
to death gives her the right to say: "Husband, I come!"
To mention Professor Raleigh again:
speaking of anachronisms in Shakespeare, he
writes:
"There are clocks in 'Julius Cesar,' a paper
mill and printing in 'Henry VI,' etc, etc. InRoman plays, Shakespeare

THE NEW BOOK SHELF.

Last month the fifteenth volume of the New
Variorum Shakespeare—"Antony and Cleopatra"—was published, being the first volume
which Dr. Furness has issued since the fall of
1904.

"0 that I were
Upon the hill of Basan to outroar
The horned herd."

The only comment on this latter fact in Dr.
Furness' edition is quoted from Singer, who
suggests that Antony may have learnt the

6

'1'1 E NEWS-LETTER.

psalms from Herod, who was his friend. In a
recent letter to the present writer Dr. Furness
writes:
"As to the hills of Basan, I gave the references from the Bible merely to show where
Antony found his allusion, and not to any conversation with Herod, as Singer most foolishly suggests."
The passage is simply one of the many
anachronisms in Shakespeare.
The various prefaces to the New Variorum
Shakespeare form in themselves charming essays. In the preface to the present volume it
is interesting to note that Dr. Furness considers Dryden's Ali for Love "an admirable
play," an opinion long held by the present
writer, which it is pleasing to find sanctioned
by the highest authority.
A most interesting and instructive portion
of the book is the essay on the various "versions" of this tragedy, which have been written
from the middle of the sixteenth century to
the time of Mr. Bernard Shaw. It is a striking fact that the first "regular" tragedy in the
literatures both of France and of Germany is
on the subject of Cleopatra.
I cannot close this notice without a reference to the kindly humor of the venerable editor, which turns up at unexpected times in
the volumes of this wonderful Shakespeare.
Several members of the faculty here at Hopkins have the honor of Dr. Furness' friendship,
among them Prof. Bright and Prof. Haupt.
Before I had that privilege a New York gentleman (who, I hear, has been suggested as the
Turnbull lecturer this winter) described Dr.
Furness to me as "a concentrated ray of sunshine." The diffusion of this "ray" through
his pages makes the darkest vault of discussion
"a feasting presence full of light."

deserves to rank with Boswell and Lockhart
among the great biographies of the language.
The present Lord Tennyson, it must be remembered, wrote an official biography. He
was not a great critic nor a great writer. The
fact that he was the poet's son was in itself
a hinderance rather than a help. But the
Memoir contains nearly all data for future biographies, besides a store of loving personal
reminiscences.
Mr. Benson is a careful and trained writer.
Besides the volumes of essays, which are
widely known, he has contributed three volumes to the English Men of Letters series.
Of ihese, the life of "Rossetti" is not entirely
satisfactory (indeed, I have yet to read one
that is), and the "Pater" is not really complete, additional data having since been furnished by relatives to Mr. Thomas,Wright, the
author of the "official" life of Pater.
But in writing this little volume on Tennyson Mr. Benson has been eminently successful.
Of course, he can give now no new facts about
a life, the minute details of which are known
to almost everyone. It is in the criticism,
which makes up a large part of the book, that
he excells. I cannot, however, agree with
some of his opinions, notably his support of
Coventry Patmore's harsh dictum regarding
the poetry of "In Memoriam." A very charming chapter is written on Tennyson's opinions
of various poets—Shakespeare, Milton, Keats,
'Wordsworth, etc. It is interesting and touching to know that Tennyson died with a volume
of Shakespeare clasped in his hand. This is
told in the Memoir, but from Mr. Benson I
learn for the first time that the book was
opened at and his finger rested on the lines of

CARE FREE.
Come, leave with me, my autumn love,
,The Republic of Reality,
And climb up to that land above—
The Kingdom of Care-Free.
Ah, leave behind you everything—
Forget you're but eighteen,
And I will be my lady's king,
And you shall be my queen.
Up, up the radiant stairs of Chance,
The topmost step we'll reach—
And them come forth where faeries dance
Upon a silver beach.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the novels repels us. Words, words, words!
To say the least Richardson is prolix. But
Richardson is a moral writer. The moral of
the novel, a thing of but little importance to
either Fielding or Smollett, was.of supreme
importance to him. When Pamela or Virtue
Rewarded, appeared the clergy hailed it with
joy. It was to them as assistance from the
enemy. Richardson modestly sums up his
novel in the following sentence:
"Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded, is a series of
familiar letters from a beautiful young damsel to her parents, published in order to cultivate the principles of virtue and religion in the
minds of the youth of both sexes ; a narrative
which has its foundation in truth, and at the
same time that it agreeably entertains by a
variety of curious and affecting incidents, is
entirely divested of all those images which in
too many pieces calculated for amusement
only, tend to inflame the minds that they
should instruct." This is something of a sentence, even, for Richardson.
In this novel we have the struggle of virtue
and vice. Indeed, before I had half finished it,
I was tempted to remark that it was the greatgrand daddy of all Sunday school libraries.
Pamela believes everything is good. She is
the very apotheosis of virtue and submissiveness. Her master is diametrically the opposite. And so the story drags through four
long volumes. At one time it seems that virtue
must lose. Pamela falls in love with her master, but her native innocence helps and stays
her. At last the wicked master weakens. lie
will marry the foolish little girl. For her wedding present she obtains the pardon of the very
people who had ill-treated her. And so the
story goes.
But is Pamela a real person ? I should say
certainly not, although the ladies would contradict me. The master is, but his very vices
tend to show all the more the almost impossible goodness of Pamela.
Clarissa liar/owe is much like Pamela.
Here we have a delightful picture of family
life : a stern old demon of a father, an envious elder sister, a regular hot-blooded bulldog of an elder son, a couple of surly old
uncles and a beautiful young daughter, Clarissa.
But the characters in Clarissa Harlow are

more human than those in Pamela. Richardson, in Clarissa HarloTce, gave one character
to English Literature—that of Lovelace.
.Lovelace, with all the malice and venom of a
viper, poses as a brilliant, witty, young beau.
lie only cares for those who offer some resistance to his charms. Lovelace is one of the
least attractive of all Richardson's characters,
but he is the only one who has ever obtained
prominence. He remains today, one of the
characters of English literature, ranking beside Colonel Newcome, Mr. Pickwick, Mr.
Micawber, only how different!
Yet in Clarissa Harlow( Richardson falls
into the same old fault—prolixity. What does
the reader care whether Clarissa Harlowe's
coffin has silver or tin handles? Does it make
any difference to us if the same old coffin is
lined with pink silk or yellow satin ? But it
evidently does matter to the author. I le 'must
write chapters on that subject.
Richardson, seeking to aid morality, unwittingly prejudices the reader against it. He
seems to forget that one well-placed word
has more effect on the reader than twenty
pages of explanation. The reader laughs at
the pathetic parts. in the parts intended to be
elevating, the reader sees only the ranting
preacher.
But Richardson is great. To understand the
English novel you must understand Richardson. When we consider the times in which
Richardson wrote we must admit the excellence of his novels. What ever may be their
faults in execution, their conception was good.
Richardson tried and just missed being a great
novelist. Fielding profited by the novels of
Richardson. Joseph . indrews, published after
Richardson's Pamela, was suggested to him
by the former novel.
Richardson did not understand men. All
his men, with the exception of Sir Charles
Grandison, are villains. And Sir Charles
Grandison seems to have stepped out of a
fashion plate. His letters seem to have been
copied from "M rs. Grundy's Complete LetterWriter." He is about as human as a clothes
dummy. Richardson was a woman's writer.
All his novels were widely read by women.
His popularity was among women. And why?
He understood a woman's mind. He appreciated the fine side of a woman's nature. He

THE NEWS-LETTER.

could sympathize with the feelings of a
woman's heart.
While we are criticising Richardson, let us
give him the credit due him. He was the first
English novelist. No one had ever gone before him, by whose mistakes he could profit.
His novels were all his own. He opened the
path where, years later, Thackeray, Dickens,
Charles Reade and Scott were to follow.

And if anything has happened in the
neighborhood of McCoy Hall, which may
not have been observed by us, but which you
think worthy of chronicling, why don't be
bashful;—write it up and hand it in! This
would demand very little exertion on your
part and would help us greatly.
There is another trouble of very different
character which grieves the life of an Editor.
This is the torments inflicted by a malignant
imp, known as the "Printer's Devil," sometimes referred to as 'that devil of a printer."
The hateful creature takes the most violent
and inexplicable dislikes to various harmless
people. In the last number of the NEWSLETTER he made a furious onslaught on several
famous poets. Hugo he maimed into "Hugh;"
the mangled corpse of Burns was scarcely
recognized as ''Bruns;'' he so crushed Plautus
that the proud capital "P" of the Latin
dramatist was deformed into "p;" Mr. Percy
McRaye became "Mr. Percy McVey." The
"Printer's Devil" also had trouble with
Tennyson's "hollow Os and As" with the
result that "Osianna" became "Asianna."
Worse than all these, our President himself
was not safe and Doctor Remsen was exhibited
to our horror-stricken gaze as "Doctor
Renzen." Another queer trait of the creature
is the hydra-like rapidity with which his mis'—multiply.
begotten offspring— misprints'
As fast as one is slain another takes its place.
To speak seriously for a moment, no one
who has not had experience in reading proof
can realize the corrections that have to be
made in "galley-proof,"and even after a second
reading one cannot be sure that no misprints
exist. The last number of the NEws-LETTER
was published hastily owing to some unavoidable delays in getting the advertising arranged
and considering the fact that only one proof
was read, and that hurriedly, the six or seven
misprints need not be a cause of great triumph
to the "Printer's Devil."
